**Hispaniola** ([Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"): _La
Española_ ; [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): _Hispaniola_ ;
[Taíno](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_\(language\) "Taíno \(language\)"):
_Haiti/Quisqueya_)[3][4] is the [22nd-largest island in the
world](/wiki/List_of_islands_by_area "List of islands by area"), located in
the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") [island group](/wiki/Island_group
"Island group"), the [Greater Antilles](/wiki/Greater_Antilles "Greater
Antilles"). It is the second largest island in the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean
"Caribbean") after [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), and the most populous island in
the Caribbean; the eleventh [most populous
island](/wiki/List_of_islands_by_population "List of islands by population")
in the world.

The 76,192-square-kilometre (29,418 sq mi) island is divided between two
sovereign nations, the Spanish-speaking [Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic") (48,445 km2, 18,705
sq mi), and French-speaking [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti") (27,750 km2, 10,710
sq mi). The only other shared island in the Caribbean is [Saint
Martin](/wiki/Saint_Martin_\(island\) "Saint Martin \(island\)"), which is
shared between [France](/wiki/France "France") ([Saint-
Martin](/wiki/Collectivity_of_Saint-Martin "Collectivity of Saint-Martin"))
and [the Netherlands](/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands "Kingdom of the
Netherlands") ([Sint Maarten](/wiki/Sint_Maarten "Sint Maarten")).

Hispaniola is the site of the first permanent European settlement in the
Americas, founded by [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus
"Christopher Columbus") on his voyages in 1492 and 1493.[5][6]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Hispaniola_Vinckeboons4.jpg/300px-
Hispaniola_Vinckeboons4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hispaniola_Vinckeboons4.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hispaniola_Vinckeboons4.jpg "Enlarge")

Early map of Hispaniola and [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), c.
1639.

See also: [Colony of Santo Domingo](/wiki/Colony_of_Santo_Domingo "Colony of
Santo Domingo"), [Colony of Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Colony_of_Saint-Domingue
"Colony of Saint-Domingue"), [History of Haiti](/wiki/History_of_Haiti
"History of Haiti"), and [History of the Dominican
Republic](/wiki/History_of_the_Dominican_Republic "History of the Dominican
Republic")

### Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

The island was called by various names by its native people, the
[Taíno](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_people "Taíno people")
[Amerindians](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of
the Americas"). No known [Taíno texts](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_language "Taíno
language") survive, hence, historical evidence for those names comes to us
through three [historians](/wiki/Historian "Historian"): the Italian [Pietro
Martyr d‘Anghiera](/wiki/Peter_Martyr_d%27Anghiera "Peter Martyr d'Anghiera"),
and the Spaniards [Bartolomé de las Casas](/wiki/Bartolom%C3%A9_de_las_Casas
"Bartolomé de las Casas") and [Gonzalo Fernández de
Oviedo](/wiki/Gonzalo_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Oviedo_y_Vald%C3%A9s "Gonzalo
Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés"). Fernández de Oviedo and de las Casas both
recorded that the island was called _Haiti_ ("Mountainous Land") by the Taíno.
D'Anghiera added another name, _Quizqueia_ (supposedly "Mother of all Lands"),
but later research shows that the word does not seem to derive from the
original [Arawak](/wiki/Arawakan_languages "Arawakan languages") Taíno
language.[3] (_Quisqueya_ is today mostly used in the [Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic").) Although the
Taínos' use of _Haiti_ is verified, and the name was used by all three
historians, evidence suggests that it probably was not the Taíno name of the
whole island, but only for a region (now known as _[Los
Haitises](/wiki/Los_Haitises_National_Park "Los Haitises National Park")_) in
the northeastern section of the present-day Dominican Republic.

When Columbus took possession of the island in 1492, he named it
_Insula[Hispana](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania")_ in [Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin")[7] and _La Isla Española_ in Spanish,[8] with both meaning "the
Spanish island". De las Casas shortened the name to "Española", and when
d‘Anghiera detailed his account of the island in [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"),
he rendered its name as _Hispaniola_.[8] In the oldest documented map of the
island, created by Andrés de Morales, Los Haitises is labeled _Montes de
Haití_ ("Haiti Mountains"), and de las Casas apparently named the whole island
Haiti on the basis of that particular region,[4] as d'Anghiera states that the
name of one part was given to the whole island.[3]

Due to Taíno, Spanish and French influences on the island, historically the
whole island was often referred to as _Haiti,_ _Hayti,_ _Santo Domingo,_ _St.
Domingue,_ or _San Domingo._ The colonial terms _[Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Saint-
Domingue "Saint-Domingue")_ and _[Santo
Domingo](/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Santo_Domingo "Captaincy General of Santo
Domingo")_ are sometimes still applied to the whole island, though these names
refer, respectively, to the colonies that became Haiti and the Dominican
Republic.[9] Since Anghiera's literary work was translated into
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") and
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language") soon after being written,
the name "Hispaniola" became the most frequently used term in English-speaking
countries for the island in scientific and cartographic works. In 1918, the
United States occupation government, led by [Harry Shepard
Knapp](/wiki/Harry_Shepard_Knapp "Harry Shepard Knapp"), obliged the use of
the name Hispaniola on the island, and recommended the use of that name to the
[National Geographic Society](/wiki/National_Geographic_Society "National
Geographic Society").[10]

The name _Haïti_ was adopted by Haitian revolutionary [Jean-Jacques
Dessalines](/wiki/Jean-Jacques_Dessalines "Jean-Jacques Dessalines") in 1804,
as the official name of independent Saint-Domingue, as a tribute to the
Amerindian predecessors. It was also adopted as the official name of
independent Santo Domingo, as the _[Republic of Spanish
Haiti](/wiki/Republic_of_Spanish_Haiti "Republic of Spanish Haiti"),_ a state
that existed from November 1821 until its annexation by Haiti in February
1822.[11][12]

### Post-Columbian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Post-Columbian")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Columbus_landing_on_Hispaniola_adj.jpg/220px-
Columbus_landing_on_Hispaniola_adj.jpg)](/wiki/File:Columbus_landing_on_Hispaniola_adj.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Columbus_landing_on_Hispaniola_adj.jpg "Enlarge")

Columbus landing on Hispaniola

[Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher Columbus")
inadvertently landed on the island during his first voyage across the Atlantic
in 1492, where his flagship, the _[Santa Maria](/wiki/Santa_Maria_\(ship\)
"Santa Maria \(ship\)")_ , sank after running aground on December 25. A
contingent of men were left at an outpost christened [La
Navidad](/wiki/La_Navidad "La Navidad"), on the north coast of present-day
[Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti"). On his return the following year,[13] following
the destruction of La Navidad by the local population, Columbus quickly
established a second compound farther east in present-day [Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic"), [La
Isabela](/wiki/La_Isabela "La Isabela").

The island was inhabited by the [Taíno](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_people "Taíno
people"), one of the indigenous [Arawak peoples](/wiki/Arawak_peoples "Arawak
peoples"). The Taino were at first tolerant of Columbus and his crew, and
helped him to construct [La Navidad](/wiki/La_Navidad "La Navidad") on what is
now [Môle-Saint-Nicolas](/wiki/M%C3%B4le-Saint-Nicolas "Môle-Saint-Nicolas"),
Haiti, in December 1492. European colonization of the island began in earnest
the following year, when 1,300 men arrived from [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain")
under the watch of [Bartolomeo Columbus](/wiki/Bartolomeo_Columbus "Bartolomeo
Columbus"). In 1496 the town of _Nueva Isabela_ was founded. After being
destroyed by a [hurricane](/wiki/Hurricane "Hurricane"), it was rebuilt on the
opposite side of the Ozama River and called [Santo
Domingo](/wiki/Santo_Domingo "Santo Domingo"). It is the oldest permanent
European settlement in the Americas.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Copia_de_Cacicazgos_de_la_Hispaniola.png/296px-
Copia_de_Cacicazgos_de_la_Hispaniola.png)](/wiki/File:Copia_de_Cacicazgos_de_la_Hispaniola.png)

[](/wiki/File:Copia_de_Cacicazgos_de_la_Hispaniola.png "Enlarge")

[Chiefdoms of Hispaniola](/wiki/Chiefdoms_of_Hispaniola "Chiefdoms of
Hispaniola")

Several 16th century writers estimated the 1492 population of Hispaniola at
over 1 million people.[14] Twentieth-century estimates of the figure range
from 60,000 to 8,000,000, but center around the 500,000 to 1,000,000
range.[14] Harsh enslavement by Spanish colonists, redirection of food
supplies and labor towards the colonists, had a devastating impact on both
mortality and fertility over the first quarter century.[15] Colonial
administrators and Dominican and Hyeronimite priests observed that the search
for gold and agrarian enslavement through the encomienda system were
depressing population.[15] Demographic data from two provinces in 1514 shows a
low birth rate consistent with a 3.5% annual population decline. Just 14,000
Taínos survived in 1517.[16] In 1503 the colony began to import
[African](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa "Ethnic groups of Africa")
[slaves](/wiki/Slaves "Slaves"), believing them more capable of performing
physical labor.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The first documented outbreak of smallpox, previously an Eastern hemisphere
disease, on Hispaniola occurred in December 1518 among enslaved African
miners.[15][17] Some scholars speculate that European diseases arrived before
this date, but there is no compelling evidence for an outbreak.[15] The
natives had no immunity to European diseases, including
[smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox "Smallpox").[18][19] By May 1519, as many as one-
third of the remaining Taínos had died.[17]

Christopher Columbus brought sugar cane on his second voyage to the island.
Molasses was the chief product. Diego Colon's plantation had 40 African slaves
in 1522. By 1526, 19 mills were in operation from Azua to Santo
Domingo.[20]:224

In 1574, a census taken of the Greater Antilles reported 1,000 Spaniards and
12,000 African slaves on Hispaniola.[21]

As Spain conquered new regions on the mainland of the Americas ([Spanish
Main](/wiki/Spanish_Main "Spanish Main")), its interest in Hispaniola waned,
and the colony’s population grew slowly. By the early 17th century, the island
and its smaller neighbors (notably [Tortuga](/wiki/Tortuga_\(Haiti\) "Tortuga
\(Haiti\)")) became regular stopping points for [Caribbean
pirates](/wiki/Piracy_in_the_Caribbean "Piracy in the Caribbean"). In 1606,
the government of [Philip III](/wiki/Philip_III_of_Spain "Philip III of
Spain") ordered all inhabitants of Hispaniola to move close to Santo Domingo,
to avoid interaction with pirates. Rather than secure the island, his action
meant that French, English and Dutch pirates established their own bases on
the abandoned north and west coasts of the island.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Map_of_Hispaniola.JPG/300px-
Map_of_Hispaniola.JPG)](/wiki/File:Map_of_Hispaniola.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_Hispaniola.JPG "Enlarge")

French map of Hispaniola by Nicolas de Fer

In 1665, French colonization of the island was officially recognized by [King
Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV "Louis XIV"). The French colony was given the name
[Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Saint-Domingue "Saint-Domingue"). In the 1697 [Treaty
of Ryswick](/wiki/Treaty_of_Ryswick "Treaty of Ryswick"), Spain formally ceded
the western third of the island to France.[22][23] Saint-Domingue quickly came
to overshadow the east in both [wealth](/wiki/Wealth "Wealth") and
[population](/wiki/Population "Population"). Nicknamed the "Pearl of the
Antilles," it became the richest and most prosperous colony in the [West
Indies](/wiki/West_Indies "West Indies"), with a system of human enslavement
used to grow and harvest sugar cane, during a time when demand for sugar was
high in Europe. Slavery kept prices low and profit was maximized at the
expense of human lives. It was an important port in the Americas for goods and
products flowing to and from France and Europe.

With the treaty of [Peace of Basel](/wiki/Peace_of_Basel "Peace of Basel"),
revolutionary France emerged as a major European power. In the second 1795
Treaty of Basel (July 22), Spain ceded the eastern two-thirds of the island of
Hispaniola, later to become the Dominican Republic. French settlers had begun
to colonize some areas in the Spanish side of the territory.

European colonists often died young due to tropical fevers, as well as from
violent slave resistance in the late eighteenth century. When the [French
Revolution](/wiki/French_Revolution "French Revolution") abolished slavery in
the colonies on February 4, 1794, it was a European first,[24] and when
Napoleon [reimposed slavery in 1802](/wiki/Law_of_20_May_1802 "Law of 20 May
1802") it led to a major upheaval by the emancipated black slaves.

Thousands of the French troops sent by Napoleon to reestablish slavery
succumbed to [yellow fever](/wiki/Yellow_fever "Yellow fever") during the
summer months, and more than half of the French army died because of
disease.[25] After the French removed the surviving 7,000 troops in late 1803,
the leaders of the revolution declared western Hispaniola the new nation of
independent Haiti in early 1804. France continued to rule Spanish Santo
Domingo. In 1805, Haitian troops of General [Henri
Christophe](/wiki/Henri_Christophe "Henri Christophe") tried to conquer all of
Hispaniola. They invaded Santo Domingo and sacked the towns of Santiago de los
Caballeros and Moca, killing most of their residents, but news of a French
fleet sailing towards Haiti forced General Christophe to return to Haiti,
leaving the eastern Spanish side of the island in French hands. In 1808,
following Napoleon's invasion of Spain, the [criollos](/wiki/Criollo_people
"Criollo people") of Santo Domingo revolted against French rule and, with the
aid of the United Kingdom (Spain's ally) returned Santo Domingo to Spanish
control.

Fearing the influence of a society that had successfully fought and won
against their enslavers, the United States and European powers refused to
recognize Haiti, the second republic in the western hemisphere. France
demanded a high payment for compensation to slaveholders who lost their
property, and Haiti was saddled with unmanageable debt for decades.[26] It
became one of the poorest countries in the Americas, while the Dominican
Republic [26] gradually has developed into the largest economy of [Central
America](/wiki/Central_America "Central America") and the
[Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean").

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Geography")]

See also: [Geography of Haiti](/wiki/Geography_of_Haiti "Geography of Haiti")
and [Geography of the Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Geography_of_the_Dominican_Republic "Geography of the
Dominican Republic")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Hispaniola_lrg.jpg/300px-
Hispaniola_lrg.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hispaniola_lrg.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hispaniola_lrg.jpg "Enlarge")

Topographic map of Hispaniola

Hispaniola is the second-largest island in the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean
"Caribbean") (after [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba")), with an area of 76,192 square
kilometers (29,418 sq mi), 48,440 square kilometers (18,700 sq mi)[27] of
which is under the sovereignty of the [Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic") occupying the eastern
portion and 27,750 square kilometers (10,710 sq mi)[6] under the sovereignty
of [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti") occupying the western portion.

The island of Cuba lies 80 kilometers (50 mi) to the northwest across the
[Windward Passage](/wiki/Windward_Passage "Windward Passage"); to the
southwest lies [Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica"), separated by the [Jamaica
Channel](/wiki/Jamaica_Channel "Jamaica Channel"). [Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") lies east of Hispaniola across the
[Mona Passage](/wiki/Mona_Passage "Mona Passage"). [The
Bahamas](/wiki/The_Bahamas "The Bahamas") and [Turks and Caicos
Islands](/wiki/Turks_and_Caicos_Islands "Turks and Caicos Islands") lie to the
north. Its westernmost point is known as Cap Carcasse.

Cuba, Hispaniola, Jamaica, and Puerto Rico are collectively known as the
[Greater Antilles](/wiki/Greater_Antilles "Greater Antilles").

The island has five major mountain ranges: The Central Range, known in the
Dominican Republic as the _[Cordillera
Central](/wiki/Cordillera_Central,_Dominican_Republic "Cordillera Central,
Dominican Republic")_ , spans the central part of the island, extending from
the south coast of the Dominican Republic into northwestern Haiti, where it is
known as the _Massif du Nord_. This mountain range boasts the highest peak in
the Antilles, [Pico Duarte](/wiki/Pico_Duarte "Pico Duarte") at 3,098 meters
(10,164 ft) above [sea level](/wiki/Sea_level "Sea level"). The _[Cordillera
Septentrional](/wiki/Cordillera_Septentrional "Cordillera Septentrional")_
runs parallel to the Central Range across the northern end of the Dominican
Republic, extending into the Atlantic Ocean as the [Samaná
Peninsula](/wiki/Saman%C3%A1_Peninsula "Samaná Peninsula"). The _Cordillera
Central_ and _Cordillera Septentrional_ are separated by the lowlands of the
[Cibao Valley](/wiki/Cibao "Cibao") and the Atlantic coastal plains, which
extend westward into Haiti as the _Plaine du Nord_ (Northern Plain). The
lowest of the ranges is the _Cordillera Oriental_ , in the eastern part of the
country.[28]

The _Sierra de Neiba_ rises in the southwest of the Dominican Republic, and
continues northwest into Haiti, parallel to the _Cordillera Central_ , as the
_Montagnes Noires_ , _Chaîne des Matheux_ and the _Montagnes du Trou d 'Eau_.
_The Plateau Central_ lies between the _[Massif du Nord](/wiki/Massif_du_Nord
"Massif du Nord")_ and the _Montagnes Noires_ , and the _Plaine de
l‘Artibonite_ lies between the _Montagnes Noires_ and the _Chaîne des Matheux_
, opening westward toward the [Gulf of Gonâve](/wiki/Gulf_of_Gon%C3%A2ve "Gulf
of Gonâve"), the largest gulf of the Antilles.[28]

The southern range begins in the southwestern most Dominican Republic as the
[Sierra de Bahoruco](/wiki/Baoruco_Mountain_Range "Baoruco Mountain Range"),
and extends west into Haiti as the [Massif de la
Selle](/wiki/Massif_de_la_Selle "Massif de la Selle") and the [Massif de la
Hotte](/wiki/Massif_de_la_Hotte "Massif de la Hotte"), which form the
mountainous spine of Haiti’s southern peninsula. [Pic de la
Selle](/wiki/Pic_la_Selle "Pic la Selle") is the highest peak in the southern
range, the third highest peak in the Antilles and consequently the highest
point in Haiti, at 2,680 meters (8,790 ft) above sea level. A
[depression](/wiki/Depression_\(geology\) "Depression \(geology\)") runs
parallel to the southern range, between the southern range and the _Chaîne des
Matheux_ -_Sierra de Neiba_. It is known as the _[Plaine du Cul-de-
Sac](/wiki/Plaine_du_Cul-de-Sac "Plaine du Cul-de-Sac")_ in Haiti, and Haiti’s
capital [Port-au-Prince](/wiki/Port-au-Prince "Port-au-Prince") lies at its
western end. The depression is home to a chain of [salt lakes](/wiki/Salt_lake
"Salt lake"), including [Lake Azuei](/wiki/Etang_Saum%C3%A2tre "Etang
Saumâtre") in Haiti and [Lake Enriquillo](/wiki/Lake_Enriquillo "Lake
Enriquillo") in the Dominican Republic.[28]

The island has four distinct [ecoregions](/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion"). The
[Hispaniolan moist forests](/wiki/Hispaniolan_moist_forests "Hispaniolan moist
forests") ecoregion covers approximately 50% of the island, especially the
northern and eastern portions, predominantly in the lowlands but extending up
to 2,100 meters (6,900 ft) elevation. The [Hispaniolan dry
forests](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniolan_dry_forests&action=edit&redlink=1
"Hispaniolan dry forests \(page does not exist\)") ecoregion occupies
approximately 20% of the island, lying in the [rain shadow](/wiki/Rain_shadow
"Rain shadow") of the mountains in the southern and western portion of the
island and in the [Cibao](/wiki/Cibao "Cibao") valley in the center-north of
the island. The [Hispaniolan pine forests](/wiki/Hispaniolan_pine_forests
"Hispaniolan pine forests") occupy the mountainous 15% of the island, above
850 metres (2,790 ft) elevation. The [flooded grasslands and
savannas](/wiki/Flooded_grasslands_and_savannas "Flooded grasslands and
savannas") ecoregion in the south central region of the island surrounds a
chain of lakes and lagoons in which the most notable include that of [Lake
Azuei](/wiki/Etang_Saumatre "Etang Saumatre") and [Trou
Caïman](/wiki/Trou_Ca%C3%AFman "Trou Caïman") in Haiti and the nearby [Lake
Enriquillo](/wiki/Lake_Enriquillo "Lake Enriquillo") in the Dominican
Republic.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Fauna[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Fauna")]

There are many [bird species in Hispaniola](/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Hispaniola
"List of birds of Hispaniola"), and [the island's amphibian
species](/wiki/List_of_amphibians_of_Hispaniola "List of amphibians of
Hispaniola") are also diverse.

### Flora[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Flora")]

The island has four distinct [ecoregions](/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion"). The
[Hispaniolan moist forests](/wiki/Hispaniolan_moist_forests "Hispaniolan moist
forests") ecoregion covers approximately 50% of the island, especially the
northern and eastern portions, predominantly in the lowlands but extending up
to 2,100 meters (6,900 ft) elevation. The Hispaniolan dry forests ecoregion
occupies approximately 20% of the island, lying in the [rain
shadow](/wiki/Rain_shadow "Rain shadow") of the mountains in the southern and
western portion of the island and in the [Cibao](/wiki/Cibao "Cibao") valley
in the center-north of the island. The [Hispaniolan pine
forests](/wiki/Hispaniolan_pine_forests "Hispaniolan pine forests") occupy the
mountainous 15% of the island, above 850 metres (2,790 ft) elevation. The
[flooded grasslands and savannas](/wiki/Flooded_grasslands_and_savannas
"Flooded grasslands and savannas") ecoregion in the south central region of
the island surrounds a chain of lakes and lagoons in which the most notable
include that of [Lake Azuei](/wiki/Etang_Saumatre "Etang Saumatre") and [Trou
Caïman](/wiki/Trou_Ca%C3%AFman "Trou Caïman") in Haiti and the nearby [Lake
Enriquillo](/wiki/Lake_Enriquillo "Lake Enriquillo") in the Dominican
Republic.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Haiti_deforestation.jpg/235px-
Haiti_deforestation.jpg)](/wiki/File:Haiti_deforestation.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Haiti_deforestation.jpg "Enlarge")

Satellite image depicting the border between [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti")
(left) and the [Dominican Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican
Republic") (right)

In Haiti, [deforestation](/wiki/Deforestation_in_Haiti "Deforestation in
Haiti") has long been cited by scientists as a source of ecological crisis;
the timber industry dates back to French colonial rule.

Haiti has seen a dramatic reduction of forests due to the excessive and
increasing use of [charcoal](/wiki/Charcoal "Charcoal") as fuel for cooking.
Recent in-depth studies of satellite imagery and environmental analysis
regarding forest classification conclude an accurate estimate of approximately
30% tree cover,[29] a stark decrease in the 60% forest cover in 1925. Despite
recent in-depth studies, the notoriously unsubstantiated 2% forest cover
estimate has been widely circulated in media and in discourse concerning the
country.[30] Despite the drastic underestimation of Haiti's forest cover, the
country has been significantly deforested over the last 50 years, resulting in
the desertification of portions of the Haitian territory.

In the [Dominican Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic") the
forest cover has increased. In 2003 the Dominican forest cover had been
reduced to 32% of the territory, but in 2011 the trend towards reducing
reverts to increase [forest](/wiki/Forest "Forest") cover by eight percentage
points to stand at nearly 40% of territory. The success of the Dominican
forest growth is due to several Dominican government policies and private
organizations for the purpose, and a strong educational campaign that has
resulted in increased awareness on the [Dominican
people](/wiki/People_of_the_Dominican_Republic "People of the Dominican
Republic") of the importance of forests for their welfare and in other forms
of life on the [island](/wiki/Island "Island").[31]

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Climate")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Cordillera_Central.jpg/220px-
Cordillera_Central.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cordillera_Central.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cordillera_Central.jpg "Enlarge")

[Cordillera Central](/wiki/Cordillera_Central,_Dominican_Republic "Cordillera
Central, Dominican Republic"), Dominican Republic

Owing to its mountainous topography, Hispaniola’s climate shows considerable
variation over short distances, and is the most varied of all the
[Antilles](/wiki/Antilles "Antilles").[32]

Except in the Northern Hemisphere summer season, the predominant winds over
Hispaniola are the northeast [trade winds](/wiki/Trade_winds "Trade winds").
As in Jamaica and Cuba, these winds deposit their moisture on the northern
mountains, and create a distinct [rain shadow](/wiki/Rain_shadow "Rain
shadow") on the southern coast, where some areas receive as little as 400
millimetres (16 in) of rainfall, and have [semi-arid climates](/wiki/Semi-
arid_climate "Semi-arid climate"). Annual rainfall under 600 millimetres (24
in) also occurs on the southern coast of Haiti’s northwest peninsula and in
the central Azúa region of the _Plaine du Cul-de-Sac_. In these regions,
moreover, there is generally little rainfall outside hurricane season from
August to October, and droughts are by no means uncommon when hurricanes do
not come.[33]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/View_of_Haitian_Landscape_hispaniola.jpg/220px-
View_of_Haitian_Landscape_hispaniola.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_of_Haitian_Landscape_hispaniola.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:View_of_Haitian_Landscape_hispaniola.jpg "Enlarge")

[Les Cayes](/wiki/Les_Cayes "Les Cayes"), [Sud](/wiki/Sud_\(department\) "Sud
\(department\)"), Haiti

On the northern coast, in contrast, rainfall may peak between December and
February, though some rain falls in all months of the year. Annual amounts
typically range from 1,700 to 2,000 millimetres (67 to 79 in) on the northern
coastal lowlands;[32] there is probably much more in the [Cordillera
Septentrional](/wiki/Cordillera_Septentrional "Cordillera Septentrional"),
though no data exist.

The interior of Hispaniola, along with the southeastern coast centred around
Santo Domingo, typically receives around 1,400 millimetres (55 in) per year,
with a distinct wet season from May to October. Usually, this wet season has
two peaks: one around May, the other around the hurricane season. In the
interior highlands, rainfall is much greater, around 3,100 millimetres (120
in) per year, but with a similar pattern to that observed in the central
lowlands.

As is usual for tropical islands, variations of temperature are much less
marked than rainfall variations, and depend only on altitude. Lowland
Hispaniola is generally oppressively hot and humid, with temperatures
averaging 28 °C (82 °F). with high humidity during the daytime, and around 20
°C (68 °F) at night. At higher altitudes, temperatures fall steadily, so that
[frosts](/wiki/Frost "Frost") occur during the dry season on the highest
peaks, where maxima are no higher than 18 °C (64 °F).

## Demographics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Demographics")]

The Dominican Republic is a [Hispanophone](/wiki/Hispanophone "Hispanophone")
nation of approximately 10 million people. Spanish is spoken by all Dominicans
as a primary language. Roman Catholicism is the official and dominant
religion.

Haiti is a [Francophone](/wiki/Geographical_distribution_of_French_speakers
"Geographical distribution of French speakers") nation of roughly 10 million
people. Although French is spoken as a primary language by the educated and
wealthy minority, virtually the entire population speaks [Haitian
Creole](/wiki/Haitian_Creole "Haitian Creole"), one of several French-derived
creole languages. Roman Catholicism is the dominant religion, practiced by
more than half the population, although in some cases in combination with
[Haitian Vodou](/wiki/Haitian_Vodou "Haitian Vodou") faith. Another 25% of the
populace belong to [Protestant](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism")
churches.[34] Haiti emerged as the first Black republic[35] in the world.

### Ethnic
composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Ethnic composition")]

The ethnic composition of the Dominican population is 73% mixed
(African/European), 16% white and 11% black.

The ethnic composition of Haiti is estimated to be 95% black, 5% white and
mixed.

## Economics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Economics")]

The island has the largest economy in the [Greater
Antilles](/wiki/Greater_Antilles "Greater Antilles"), however most of the
economic development is found in the Dominican Republic, the Dominican economy
being nearly 800% larger than the Haitian economy.

The estimated [annual per capita
income](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(PPP\)_per_capita "List of countries
by GDP \(PPP\) per capita") is US$1,300 in Haiti and US$8,200 in Dominican
Republic.[36]

The divergence between the level of economic development between
[Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti") and [Dominican Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic
"Dominican Republic") makes its border the higher contrast of all western land
borders and is evident that the Dominican Republic has one of the highest
migration issues in the Americas.[37]

## Precious metals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hispaniola&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Precious metals")]

Christopher Columbus, noting "the land and trees resembled those of Spain, and
that the sailors caught in their nets many fish like those of Spain...named it
Espanola on Sunday, December 9th." One of the first inhabitants he came across
on this island was "a girl wearing only a gold nose plug." Columbus later
learned that the "land of gold was farther east." Soon the Tainos were trading
pieces of gold for hawk's bells with their [cacique](/wiki/Cacique "Cacique")
declaring the gold came from [Cibao](/wiki/Cibao "Cibao"). Traveling further
east from Navidad, Columbus came across the [Yaque del Norte
River](/wiki/Yaque_del_Norte_River "Yaque del Norte River"), which he named
Rio de Oro because its "sands abound in gold dust."[38]

On Columbus' return during his second voyage he learned it was the cacique
Caonabo, "lord of the mines", who had massacred his settlement at Navidad.
While Columbus established a new settlement at [La Isabela](/wiki/La_Isabela
"La Isabela") on Jan. 1494, he sent [Alonso de Ojeda](/wiki/Alonso_de_Ojeda
"Alonso de Ojeda") and 15 men to search for the "mines of Cibao." After a six-
day journey, Ojeda came across an area "very rich in gold", in which the
"Indians took gold out of a brook...and many other streams in that province."
Columbus himself visited the mines of Cibao on 12 March 1494. He constructed
the Fort of Santo Tomas, present day [Janico](/wiki/Janico "Janico"), with
Captain Pedro Margarit in command of 56 men.[38]:119,122–126

On 24 March 1495, Columbus with his ally [Guacanagarix](/wiki/Guacanagarix
"Guacanagarix"), embarked on a war of revenge against Caonabo, capturing him
and his family while "killing many Indians and capturing others." Afterwards,
"every person of fourteen years of age or upward was to pay a large hawk's
bell of gold dust."[38]:149–150

Miguel Diaz and [Francisco de Garay](/wiki/Francisco_de_Garay "Francisco de
Garay") discovered large [gold nuggets](/wiki/Gold_nugget "Gold nugget") on
the lower [Haina River](/wiki/Haina_River "Haina River") in 1496. These San
Cristobal mines were later known as the Minas Viejas mines. Then, in 1499, the
first major discovery of gold was made in the [cordillera](/wiki/Cordillera
"Cordillera") central, which led to a mining boom. By 1501, Columbus' cousin
Giovanni Colombo, had discovered gold near Buenaventura, the deposits were
later known as Minas Nuevas. Two major mining areas resulted, one along [San
Cristobal](/wiki/San_Cristobal,_Dominican_Republic "San Cristobal, Dominican
Republic")-Buenaventura, and another in Cibao within the [La
Vega](/wiki/La_Vega,_Dominican_Republic "La Vega, Dominican
Republic")-Cotuy-[Bonao](/wiki/Bonao "Bonao") triangle, while [Santiago de los
Caballeros](/wiki/Santiago_de_los_Caballeros "Santiago de los Caballeros"),
[Concepcion](/wiki/La_Vega,_Dominican_Republic "La Vega, Dominican Republic"),
and Bonao became mining towns. The [gold rush](/wiki/Gold_rush "Gold rush") of
1500–1508 ensued.[20]

[Ferdinand](/wiki/Ferdinand_II_of_Aragon "Ferdinand II of Aragon") "ordered
gold from the richest mines reserved for the Crown." Thus, Ovando expropriated
the gold mines of Miguel Diaz and Francisco de Garay in 1504, as pit mines
became royal mines, though [placers](/wiki/Placer_mining "Placer mining") were
open to private prospectors. Furthermore, Ferdinand wanted the "best Indians"
working his royal mines, and kept 967 in the San Cristobal mining area
supervised by salaried miners.[20]:68,71,78,125–127

Under [Nicolás de Ovando y
Cáceres](/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_de_Ovando_y_C%C3%A1ceres "Nicolás de Ovando y
Cáceres")' governorship, the Indians were made to work in the gold mines,
"where they were grossly overworked, mistreated, and underfed," according to
Pons. By 1503, the Spanish Crown legalized the distribution of Indians to work
the mines as part of the [encomienda](/wiki/Encomienda "Encomienda") system.
According to Pons, "Once the Indians entered the mines, hunger and disease
literally wiped them out." By 1508 the Indian population of about 400,000 was
reduced to 60,000, and by 1514, only 26,334 remained. About half were located
in the mining towns of Concepcion, Santiago, Santo Domingo, and Buenaventura.
The [repartimiento](/wiki/Repartimiento "Repartimiento") of 1514 accelerated
emigration of the Spanish colonists, coupled with the exhaustion of the mines.
In 1516, a smallpox epidemic killed an additional 8,000, of the remaining
11,000 Indians, in one month. By 1519, according to Pons, "Both the gold
economy and the Indian population became extinct at the same
time."[39][20]:191–192

However, writing in 1860, Courtney observed, the island is "one immense gold
field", of which the early Spaniards had "scarcely began to be developed."
Additionally, "The gold is still found in the Cibao regions as of old."[40] By
1919, Condit and Ross noted "the greater part of the Republic is covered by
concessions granted by the government for mining minerals of diverse sorts."
Besides gold, these minerals included silver, manganese, copper, magnetite,
iron and nickel.[41]

Mining operations in 2016 have taken advantage of the [volcanogenic massive
sulfide ore deposits](/wiki/Volcanogenic_massive_sulfide_ore_deposit
"Volcanogenic massive sulfide ore deposit") (VMS) around
[Maimón](/wiki/Maim%C3%B3n "Maimón"). To the northeast, the Pueblo Viejo Gold
Mine was operated by state-owned Rosario Dominicana from 1975 until 1991. In
2009, Pueblo Viejo Dominicana Corporation, formed by [Barrick
Gold](/wiki/Barrick_Gold "Barrick Gold") and [Goldcorp](/wiki/Goldcorp
"Goldcorp"), started [open-pit mining](/wiki/Open-pit_mining "Open-pit
mining") operations of the Monte Negro and Moore oxide deposits. The mined ore
is processed with [gold cyanidation](/wiki/Gold_cyanidation "Gold
cyanidation"). [Pyrite](/wiki/Pyrite "Pyrite") and
[sphalerite](/wiki/Sphalerite "Sphalerite") are the main [sulfide
minerals](/wiki/Sulfide_minerals "Sulfide minerals") found in the 120 m thick
[volcanic](/wiki/Volcanic "Volcanic")
[conglomerates](/wiki/Conglomerate_\(geology\) "Conglomerate \(geology\)") and
[agglomerates](/wiki/Agglomerate "Agglomerate"), which constitute the world's
second largest sulphidation gold deposit.[42]

Between [Bonao](/wiki/Bonao "Bonao") and Maimon, [Falconbridge
Dominicana](/wiki/Falconbridge_Ltd. "Falconbridge Ltd.") has been mining
[nickel](/wiki/Nickel "Nickel") [laterites](/wiki/Laterite "Laterite") since
1971. The Cerro de Maimon copper/gold open-pit mine southeast of Maimon has
been operated by Perilya since 2006. Copper is extracted from the sulfide
ores, while gold and silver are extracted from both the sulfide and the oxide
ores. Processing is via [froth flotation](/wiki/Froth_flotation "Froth
flotation") and cyanidation. The ore is located in the VMS [Early
Cretaceous](/wiki/Early_Cretaceous "Early Cretaceous") Maimon
[Formation](/wiki/Formation_\(geology\) "Formation \(geology\)").
[Goethite](/wiki/Goethite "Goethite") enriched with gold and silver is found
in the 30 m thick oxide cap. Below that cap is a
[supergene](/wiki/Supergene_\(geology\) "Supergene \(geology\)") zone
containing pyrite, [chalcopyrite](/wiki/Chalcopyrite "Chalcopyrite"), and
sphalerite. Below the supergene zone is found the unaltered massive sulphide
mineralization.[43]
